Problem:
Consider a complex domain function \\(z(t) = Re^{i\\theta(t)}\\) where \\(R\\) is a constant radial distance and \\(\\theta(t)\\) is a time-dependent angle. We explore the transformation under the matrix \\(M(t) = \\begin{bmatrix} \\cos(\\omega t) & -\\sin(\\omega t) \\\\ \\sin(\\omega t) & \\cos(\\omega t) \\end{bmatrix}\\) representing a rotation by \\(\\omega t\\).

If the transformation \\( M(t) \\) is applied to \\( z(0) \\) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under the function without further intervention, will the result at t = T be the same as if \\( z(0) \\) was directly evolved to t = T without the transformation?
Explanation: Applying \\( M(t) \\) changes the initial phase of the function, effectively spinning it by \\(\\omega t\\). Hence, the angle \\(\\theta(T)\\) becomes \\(\\theta(0) + \\omega T\\), which is not equal to \\(\\theta(T)\\) if directly evolved.
